aws::graph::propositions: # Flight Control and Autopilot Examination Results
The tail stabilator was in the full down position.
The pitch trim was 2 wheel notches from nose full up (manual pitch trim setting).
The pitch trim continuity was verified.
The pitch trim travel was limited to full nose up to neutral due to the tail damage.
The pitch electrical trim was operative.
The pitch electrical trim indication was verified on the Garmin MFD.
The pitch electrical trim travel was limited to full nose up to neutral due to the tail damage.
The elevator control continuity was verified.
The elevator control travel was not verified due to tail damage.
Yaw control continuity was verified.
Yaw control travel was not verified due to tail damage.
The rudder electric trim was verified as operative.
The roll control continuity was verified.
The roll control travel was not verified due to wing and aileron damage.
The speed brakes did deploy and retract when operated.
The airplane's flight controls and autopilot system were examined again on August 21, 2012.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) provided oversight for the August 21, 2012 examination.
The pitch trim wheel was manually operated during the August 21, 2012 examination.
The trim could be moved to the nose up stop during the August 21, 2012 examination.
The trim could only be moved to approximately mid-range in the nose down direction due to the damage to the tail section and empennage of the airplane.
The Garmin PFD started up normally during the August 21, 2012 examination.
The Garmin MFD started up normally during the August 21, 2012 examination.
The autopilot automated preflight test began and completed successfully during the August 21, 2012 examination.
The electric pitch trim moved nose up and nose down according to the pilot's control wheel switches.
The pilot's control wheel AP disconnect/Trim Interrupt switch interrupted the electric pitch trim when the switch was pushed and held.
The split trim switch operated normally.
The test verified that the electric pitch trim did not move when each half of the split trim switch was actuated individually.
The autopilot operated normally in the HDG (heading) mode.
The autopilot operated normally in the PIT (pitch attitude hold) mode.

text:
# The examination of the flight controls revealed the following:

1. The tail stabilator was in the full down position.

2. The pitch trim was 2 wheel notches from nose full up (manual pitch trim setting).

3. The pitch trim continuity was verified; however, the trim travel was limited to full nose up to neutral due to the tail damage that limited trim travel.

4. The pitch electrical trim was operative and indication was verified on the Garmin MFD; however, the trim travel was limited to full nose up to neutral due to the tail damage that limited trim travel.

5. The elevator control continuity was verified; however, the control travel was not verified due to tail damage.

6. Yaw control continuity was verified; however, the control travel was not verified due to tail damage.

7. The rudder electric trim was verified as operative.

8. The roll control continuity was verified; however, the control travel was not verified due to wing and aileron damage.

9. The speed brakes did deploy and retract when operated.

## TESTS AND RESEARCH

### Flight Controls and Autopilot

The airplane's flight controls and autopilot system were examined again on August 21, 2012, with National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) oversight. The autopilot and flight controls were examined with the following results:

1. The pitch trim wheel was manually operated. The trim could be moved to the nose up stop, but only to approximately mid-range in the nose down direction due to the damage to the tail section and empennage of the airplane.

2. The Garmin PFD and MFD started up normally. The autopilot automated preflight test began and completed successfully.

3. Using the pilot's control wheel switches, the electric pitch trim moved nose up and nose down accordingly. The pilot's control wheel AP disconnect/Trim Interrupt switch interrupted the electric pitch trim when the switch was pushed and held.

4. The split trim switch operated normally. The test verified that the electric pitch trim did not move when each half was actuated individually.

5. The autopilot operated normally in the HDG (heading) and PIT (pitch attitude hold) modes.

---
